metadata.dotPoint: Comparison of exothermic and endothermic reactions, with reference to bond making and bond breaking, including enthalpy changes (ŒîH) measured in kJ, molar enthalpy changes measured in kJ mol‚Åª¬π and enthalpy changes for mixtures measured in kJ g‚Åª¬π, and their representations in energy profile diagrams

bond_breaking_energy.name: Bond Breaking Requires Energy
bond_breaking_energy.correct: Breaking chemical bonds ALWAYS requires energy input from the surroundings. This is an endothermic process.

releases energy.error: Reversed. Breaking bonds needs energy IN, not out.
releases energy.fix: Think of it like breaking a stick‚Äîyou must put in effort (energy) to snap it apart.
releases energy.action: Remember: break = take (energy). You take energy from surroundings to break bonds.

neither absorbs nor releases energy.error: Bond breaking definitely involves energy transfer.
neither absorbs nor releases energy.fix: Breaking bonds requires overcoming the attractive forces between atoms‚Äîthis takes energy.
neither absorbs nor releases energy.action: Consider: why do you need heat to break down molecules? Because breaking bonds costs energy.

sometimes releases energy.error: Bond breaking ALWAYS requires energy, no exceptions.
sometimes releases energy.fix: Every chemical bond represents stored energy. Breaking it always needs energy input.
sometimes releases energy.action: There are no bonds that release energy when broken. This is a fundamental rule.

persistent.gap: You have the bond energy concept backwards.
persistent.action: Write 10 times: Breaking bonds REQUIRES energy. Forming bonds RELEASES energy.

bond_forming_energy.name: Bond Forming Releases Energy
bond_forming_energy.correct: Forming chemical bonds ALWAYS releases energy to the surroundings. This is an exothermic process.

requires energy.error: Reversed. Forming bonds releases energy, not requires it.
requires energy.fix: When atoms bond, they reach a lower, more stable energy state‚Äîthe excess is released.
requires energy.action: Remember: form = warm (releases heat). Forming bonds warms the surroundings.

neither absorbs nor releases energy.error: Bond formation definitely involves energy release.
neither absorbs nor releases energy.fix: Bonded atoms are more stable (lower energy) than separate atoms‚Äîthe energy difference is released.
neither absorbs nor releases energy.action: Consider why explosions release energy: many new bonds form rapidly, releasing lots of energy.

sometimes requires energy.error: Bond formation ALWAYS releases energy, no exceptions.
sometimes requires energy.fix: The very definition of a chemical bond is a lower energy arrangement. Forming one always releases energy.
sometimes requires energy.action: There are no bonds that require energy to form. This is a fundamental rule.

persistent.gap: You have the bond energy concept backwards.
persistent.action: Create a diagram: broken bonds (high energy) ‚Üí formed bonds (low energy) + released energy.

enthalpy_definition.name: Enthalpy Definition
enthalpy_definition.formula: H = internal energy of a system
enthalpy_definition.correct: Enthalpy (H) is the total heat content or internal energy of a chemical system at constant pressure.

temperature of a system.error: Temperature and enthalpy are different concepts.
temperature of a system.fix: Temperature measures average kinetic energy of particles. Enthalpy is the total internal energy content.
temperature of a system.action: A system can have high enthalpy but low temperature (and vice versa). They're not the same.

kinetic energy of particles.error: That's only part of it. Enthalpy includes more.
kinetic energy of particles.fix: Enthalpy includes ALL internal energy: kinetic, potential, and chemical bond energy.
kinetic energy of particles.action: Kinetic energy is about motion; enthalpy also includes energy stored in bonds.

activation energy of a reaction.error: Activation energy is the barrier to start a reaction, not the total energy content.
activation energy of a reaction.fix: Enthalpy (H) is stored energy. Activation energy (Ea) is the minimum energy to initiate reaction.
activation energy of a reaction.action: Ea appears as a 'hump' on energy diagrams. H is the energy level of reactants or products.

persistent.gap: You're confusing enthalpy with other energy concepts.
persistent.action: Define clearly: Enthalpy = total internal energy. Temperature = particle motion. Ea = reaction barrier.

enthalpy_change_definition.name: Enthalpy Change (ŒîH)
enthalpy_change_definition.correct: Enthalpy change (ŒîH) is the difference in enthalpy between products and reactants, measuring energy absorbed or released.

H(reactants) ‚àí H(products).fix: ŒîH = final ‚àí initial = products ‚àí reactants. This matches ŒîT = T(final) ‚àí T(initial).
H(reactants) ‚àí H(products).action: Always remember: delta (Œî) means final minus initial. Products are the final state.

energy required to start a reaction.error: That's activation energy, not enthalpy change.
energy required to start a reaction.fix: ŒîH is the net energy difference. Activation energy is the initial barrier to overcome.
energy required to start a reaction.action: On an energy diagram: Ea is the peak height above reactants. ŒîH is products minus reactants.

total energy of products only.error: ŒîH is a CHANGE, requiring comparison of two states.
total energy of products only.fix: The delta (Œî) means change or difference. You need both reactant and product enthalpy.
total energy of products only.action: ŒîH without comparing reactants and products is meaningless. It's always a difference.

persistent.gap: You don't understand what enthalpy change represents.
persistent.action: Practice: calculate ŒîH for 5 reactions. Always subtract reactants from products.

exothermic_definition.name: Exothermic Reactions
exothermic_definition.correct: Exothermic reactions release energy to surroundings. Products have LOWER enthalpy than reactants, so ŒîH is NEGATIVE.

ŒîH is positive.error: Positive ŒîH means endothermic, not exothermic.
ŒîH is positive.fix: Exo = out. Energy goes OUT, so system loses energy, making ŒîH negative.
ŒîH is positive.action: If products are lower than reactants on an energy diagram, energy was released (negative ŒîH).

products are higher in energy.fix: In exothermic reactions, products are MORE STABLE (lower energy) than reactants.
products are higher in energy.action: Draw the energy diagram: reactants high, products low, arrow pointing down.

energy is absorbed from surroundings.error: Exothermic releases energy; you're describing endothermic.
energy is absorbed from surroundings.fix: Exo = out. Energy exits the system and enters the surroundings (feels warm).
energy is absorbed from surroundings.action: Think: combustion is exothermic. Fire releases heat, it doesn't absorb it.

persistent.gap: You're confusing exothermic and endothermic reactions.
persistent.action: Memorise: EXO = EXIT = energy leaves = negative ŒîH = surroundings warm up.

endothermic_definition.name: Endothermic Reactions
endothermic_definition.correct: Endothermic reactions absorb energy from surroundings. Products have HIGHER enthalpy than reactants, so ŒîH is POSITIVE.

ŒîH is negative.error: Negative ŒîH means exothermic, not endothermic.
ŒîH is negative.fix: Endo = in. Energy goes IN, so system gains energy, making ŒîH positive.
ŒîH is negative.action: If products are higher than reactants on an energy diagram, energy was absorbed (positive ŒîH).

products are lower in energy.fix: In endothermic reactions, products are LESS STABLE (higher energy) than reactants.
products are lower in energy.action: Draw the energy diagram: reactants low, products high, arrow pointing up.

energy is released to surroundings.error: Endothermic absorbs energy; you're describing exothermic.
energy is released to surroundings.fix: Endo = in. Energy enters the system from the surroundings (feels cold).
energy is released to surroundings.action: Think: ice packs are endothermic. They absorb heat, making things feel cold.

persistent.gap: You're confusing exothermic and endothermic reactions.
persistent.action: Memorise: ENDO = ENTER = energy enters = positive ŒîH = surroundings cool down.

enthalpy_equation.name: Enthalpy Change Equation
enthalpy_equation.correct: ŒîH equals total energy to break reactant bonds MINUS total energy released forming product bonds.

Œ£(bonds formed) ‚àí Œ£(bonds broken).fix: First you break bonds (costs energy), then you form bonds (releases energy). Break ‚àí Form.
Œ£(bonds formed) ‚àí Œ£(bonds broken).action: Reaction order: break first, form second. ŒîH = (breaking cost) ‚àí (forming release).

Œ£(bonds broken) + Œ£(bonds formed).error: You add when both have the same sign; these have opposite signs.
Œ£(bonds broken) + Œ£(bonds formed).fix: Breaking requires (+) energy, forming releases (‚àí) energy. Net = positive ‚àí negative = subtraction.
Œ£(bonds broken) + Œ£(bonds formed).action: One process takes energy, one gives energy. You subtract to find the net result.

Œ£(bonds broken) √ó Œ£(bonds formed).error: Bond energies are added/subtracted, not multiplied.
Œ£(bonds broken) √ó Œ£(bonds formed).fix: Total energy = sum of individual bond energies. Then compare breaking vs forming.
Œ£(bonds broken) √ó Œ£(bonds formed).action: Think of it like a budget: money spent (breaking) minus money earned (forming).

activation_energy.name: Activation Energy (Ea)
activation_energy.correct: Activation energy (Ea) is the minimum energy required for a reaction to proceed‚Äîthe energy barrier that must be overcome.

energy released by the reaction.error: That's the enthalpy change, not activation energy.
energy released by the reaction.fix: Ea is the initial barrier. ŒîH is the net energy change after reaction completes.
energy released by the reaction.action: On energy diagrams: Ea is the hump height, ŒîH is the difference between start and end.

difference between reactant and product.error: That's the definition of ŒîH, not Ea.
difference between reactant and product.fix: Ea is measured from reactants to the peak (transition state). ŒîH is reactants to products.
difference between reactant and product.action: Draw an energy profile. Ea goes up to the peak. ŒîH goes across to the products.

energy of the products.error: Ea is about the barrier, not the product energy level.
energy of the products.fix: Activation energy is the 'hill' that reactants must climb before they can become products.
energy of the products.action: Every reaction has an Ea, even very exothermic ones. It's about starting, not finishing.

persistent.gap: You're confusing activation energy with enthalpy change.
persistent.action: Label 5 energy diagrams with both Ea (barrier) and ŒîH (difference). They're different.

enthalpy_units_kJ.name: Enthalpy in kJ
enthalpy_units_kJ.correct: Enthalpy in kJ measures the TOTAL energy released or absorbed by a specific reaction as written.

energy per mole of any reactant.error: Plain kJ is total energy, not per-mole.
energy per mole of any reactant.fix: kJ gives overall energy for the reaction as written. kJ mol‚Åª¬π is per mole of a specific substance.
energy per mole of any reactant.action: Check: does the value have mol‚Åª¬π? No ‚Üí total energy. Yes ‚Üí per mole.

energy per gram of substance.error: That would be kJ g‚Åª¬π, not kJ.
energy per gram of substance.fix: kJ is total energy. kJ g‚Åª¬π is energy per gram (useful for comparing different mass fuels).
energy per gram of substance.action: Units tell you what's being measured: kJ = total, kJ g‚Åª¬π = per gram, kJ mol‚Åª¬π = per mole.

temperature change of the reaction.error: Temperature change is measured in ¬∞C or K, not kJ.
temperature change of the reaction.fix: Enthalpy (kJ) is energy content. Temperature is how hot something is. Different concepts.
temperature change of the reaction.action: Energy (kJ) can cause temperature change, but they're not the same measurement.

persistent.gap: You don't understand when to use kJ versus other enthalpy units.
persistent.action: Match scenarios to units: total heat from burning 50g fuel ‚Üí kJ. Comparing fuels ‚Üí kJ mol‚Åª¬π or kJ g‚Åª¬π.

enthalpy_units_kJ_mol.name: Molar Enthalpy (kJ mol‚Åª¬π)
enthalpy_units_kJ_mol.correct: Molar enthalpy (kJ mol‚Åª¬π) is the energy change per mole of a substance‚Äîused to compare pure compounds.

total energy of the reaction.error: kJ mol‚Åª¬π is per mole, not total.
total energy of the reaction.fix: kJ mol‚Åª¬π standardises to one mole, allowing fair comparison between different substances.
total energy of the reaction.action: To get total energy from kJ mol‚Åª¬π, multiply by number of moles.

energy per gram of substance.error: That's kJ g‚Åª¬π, not kJ mol‚Åª¬π.
energy per gram of substance.fix: mol‚Åª¬π means per mole (amount of particles). g‚Åª¬π means per gram (mass).
energy per gram of substance.action: Use kJ mol‚Åª¬π when you know moles. Use kJ g‚Åª¬π when you know mass.

energy per litre of substance.error: Per litre would be kJ L‚Åª¬π, not kJ mol‚Åª¬π.
energy per litre of substance.fix: The superscript tells you the unit: mol‚Åª¬π = per mole, L‚Åª¬π = per litre, g‚Åª¬π = per gram.
energy per litre of substance.action: Read the unit carefully. The ‚Åª¬π shows what you're dividing by.

enthalpy_units_kJ_g.name: Specific Enthalpy (kJ g‚Åª¬π)
enthalpy_units_kJ_g.correct: Specific enthalpy (kJ g‚Åª¬π) is energy per gram‚Äîuseful for comparing fuels that are mixtures or have different molar masses.

energy per mole of substance.error: That's kJ mol‚Åª¬π, not kJ g‚Åª¬π.
energy per mole of substance.fix: g‚Åª¬π means per gram (mass-based). mol‚Åª¬π means per mole (particle-based).
energy per mole of substance.action: Use kJ g‚Åª¬π when comparing by mass (e.g., which fuel gives more energy per kilogram).

total energy of the reaction.error: kJ g‚Åª¬π is per gram, not total.
total energy of the reaction.fix: To get total energy from kJ g‚Åª¬π, multiply by mass in grams.
total energy of the reaction.action: kJ g‚Åª¬π normalises to 1 gram, allowing comparison regardless of amount used.

only used for pure substances.error: kJ g‚Åª¬π is especially useful for mixtures.
only used for pure substances.fix: Mixtures don't have a single molar mass, so kJ mol‚Åª¬π doesn't work. Use kJ g‚Åª¬π instead.
only used for pure substances.action: Coal, petrol (mixtures) ‚Üí compare using kJ g‚Åª¬π. Pure methane ‚Üí can use kJ mol‚Åª¬π.

persistent.gap: You don't understand when to use kJ g‚Åª¬π.
persistent.action: List 5 fuels. For mixtures (coal, petrol), use kJ g‚Åª¬π. For pure compounds (methane), either works.

energy_profile_exothermic.name: Exothermic Energy Profile
energy_profile_exothermic.correct: In an exothermic energy profile, products are BELOW reactants. The downward drop represents energy released.

products above reactants.fix: Exothermic releases energy, so products end up at LOWER energy than reactants.
products above reactants.action: Draw it: start high (reactants), end low (products). Energy released = height difference.

no activation energy hump.error: All reactions have activation energy, even exothermic ones.
no activation energy hump.fix: Even exothermic reactions need initial energy to start. There's always a peak before products.
no activation energy hump.action: Add the Ea hump to your diagram. Reactants ‚Üí peak ‚Üí products (lower than reactants).

products at same level as reactants.error: Same level means ŒîH = 0, neither exo nor endo.
products at same level as reactants.fix: For exothermic, products must be LOWER. Equal levels would mean no net energy change.
products at same level as reactants.action: If ŒîH is negative (exothermic), products MUST be below reactants.

energy_profile_endothermic.name: Endothermic Energy Profile
energy_profile_endothermic.correct: In an endothermic energy profile, products are ABOVE reactants. The upward rise represents energy absorbed.

products below reactants.fix: Endothermic absorbs energy, so products end up at HIGHER energy than reactants.
products below reactants.action: Draw it: start low (reactants), end high (products). Energy absorbed = height difference.

activation energy equals ŒîH.error: Ea and ŒîH are different measurements.
activation energy equals ŒîH.fix: Ea is reactants to peak. ŒîH is reactants to products. In endothermic, Ea > ŒîH usually.
activation energy equals ŒîH.action: On your diagram, measure Ea and ŒîH separately. They're different vertical distances.

products at same level as reactants.error: Same level means ŒîH = 0, neither exo nor endo.
products at same level as reactants.fix: For endothermic, products must be HIGHER. Equal levels would mean no net energy change.
products at same level as reactants.action: If ŒîH is positive (endothermic), products MUST be above reactants.

persistent.gap: You can't correctly draw endothermic energy profiles.
persistent.action: Draw 5 endothermic profiles. Label: reactants (low), Ea (peak), products (high), ŒîH (positive).

stability_energy_relationship.name: Stability and Energy
stability_energy_relationship.correct: Substances with LOWER enthalpy are MORE STABLE. In exothermic reactions, products are more stable than reactants.

higher energy means more stable.error: Reversed. Higher energy means less stable.
higher energy means more stable.fix: Systems naturally move toward lower energy states. Lower energy = more stable arrangement.
higher energy means more stable.action: Think: a ball rolls downhill (to lower energy). That's the stable position.

stability is unrelated to energy.error: Stability and energy are directly connected.
stability is unrelated to energy.fix: Stability IS about energy. Stable = low energy, unlikely to change. Unstable = high energy, reactive.
stability is unrelated to energy.action: Explosives are high-energy (unstable). Combustion products like CO‚ÇÇ and H‚ÇÇO are low-energy (stable).

equal energy means most stable.error: Equal energy is neither particularly stable nor unstable.
equal energy means most stable.fix: The lowest possible energy state is most stable. Equal just means no change in stability.
equal energy means most stable.action: Compare reactants and products. Whichever is lower in energy is more stable.

bond_breaking_energy.title: Bond Breaking Requires Energy
bond_breaking_energy.content: Chemical bonds represent attractive forces between atoms. To separate bonded atoms, you must overcome this attraction, which requires energy input. This is why bond breaking is ALWAYS an endothermic process. Think of it like pulling magnets apart‚Äîyou need to do work against the attractive force.
keyPoints: Breaking bonds ALWAYS requires energy (endothermic)
Energy must come from the surroundings
Stronger bonds require more energy to break

bond_forming_energy.title: Bond Forming Releases Energy
bond_forming_energy.content: When atoms form bonds, they achieve a lower, more stable energy state. The excess energy is released to the surroundings. This is why bond formation is ALWAYS an exothermic process. Think of it like two magnets snapping together‚Äîthe attractive force does work and releases energy.
keyPoints: Forming bonds ALWAYS releases energy (exothermic)
Energy is released to the surroundings
Stronger bonds release more energy when formed

enthalpy_definition.title: Understanding Enthalpy
enthalpy_definition.content: Enthalpy (H) is the total internal energy of a chemical system at constant pressure. It includes all forms of energy: kinetic energy of particles, potential energy due to intermolecular forces, and energy stored in chemical bonds. Enthalpy cannot be measured directly, but enthalpy CHANGES (ŒîH) can be measured.
keyPoints: Symbol: H
Represents total heat content/internal energy
Cannot measure absolute enthalpy, only changes (ŒîH)

enthalpy_change_definition.title: Enthalpy Change (ŒîH)
enthalpy_change_definition.content: Enthalpy change (ŒîH) is the difference in enthalpy between products and reactants: ŒîH = H(products) ‚àí H(reactants). It tells us the net energy absorbed or released during a reaction. A negative ŒîH means energy is released (exothermic); positive ŒîH means energy is absorbed (endothermic).
enthalpy_change_definition.formula: ŒîH = H(products) ‚àí H(reactants) = Œ£(bonds broken) ‚àí Œ£(bonds formed)
keyPoints: ŒîH = products minus reactants (final ‚àí initial)
Negative ŒîH = exothermic (energy released)
Positive ŒîH = endothermic (energy absorbed)

exothermic_definition.title: Exothermic Reactions
exothermic_definition.content: Exothermic reactions release energy to the surroundings. The prefix 'exo' means 'out'. In these reactions, more energy is released forming product bonds than is required to break reactant bonds, resulting in a net energy output. The surroundings heat up, and ŒîH is negative.
keyPoints: ŒîH is negative
Products have lower enthalpy than reactants
Surroundings increase in temperature
Products are more stable than reactants

endothermic_definition.title: Endothermic Reactions
endothermic_definition.content: Endothermic reactions absorb energy from the surroundings. The prefix 'endo' means 'in'. In these reactions, more energy is required to break reactant bonds than is released forming product bonds, resulting in a net energy input. The surroundings cool down, and ŒîH is positive.
keyPoints: ŒîH is positive
Products have higher enthalpy than reactants
Surroundings decrease in temperature
Reactants are more stable than products

enthalpy_equation.title: Calculating ŒîH from Bond Energies
enthalpy_equation.content: The overall enthalpy change can be calculated from bond energies: ŒîH = Œ£(bonds broken) ‚àí Œ£(bonds formed). First, sum all the energy required to break reactant bonds. Then subtract the energy released by forming product bonds. If the result is negative, the reaction is exothermic.
enthalpy_equation.formula: ŒîH = Œ£(energy to break bonds) ‚àí Œ£(energy released forming bonds)
keyPoints: Add energy for ALL bonds broken in reactants
Subtract energy for ALL bonds formed in products
Negative result = exothermic; positive = endothermic

activation_energy.title: Activation Energy (Ea)
activation_energy.content: Activation energy is the minimum energy required for a reaction to proceed. It represents the energy barrier that must be overcome for reactant bonds to begin breaking. ALL reactions have activation energy, even highly exothermic ones. On an energy profile, Ea is the height from reactants to the peak (transition state).
keyPoints: Minimum energy to start a reaction
All reactions have Ea (even exothermic ones)
Catalysts lower Ea but don't change ŒîH
Measured from reactants to peak on energy profile

enthalpy_units_kJ.title: Enthalpy in kJ (Total Energy)
enthalpy_units_kJ.content: When enthalpy change is expressed simply in kJ (or J), it represents the TOTAL energy released or absorbed by the reaction as written. This is the actual energy involved when specific amounts react. To find total energy, multiply kJ mol‚Åª¬π by moles, or kJ g‚Åª¬π by grams.
keyPoints: Total energy for the reaction as written
Used when actual energy transfer matters
Calculate from: kJ mol‚Åª¬π √ó moles or kJ g‚Åª¬π √ó grams

enthalpy_units_kJ_mol.title: Molar Enthalpy (kJ mol‚Åª¬π)
enthalpy_units_kJ_mol.content: Molar enthalpy change (kJ mol‚Åª¬π) is the energy released or absorbed per mole of substance. This standardises the comparison‚Äîone mole is always the same number of particles. Use kJ mol‚Åª¬π when comparing pure compounds with known molar masses.
keyPoints: Energy per mole of substance
Best for comparing pure compounds
Convert to total kJ by multiplying by moles

enthalpy_units_kJ_g.title: Specific Enthalpy (kJ g‚Åª¬π)
enthalpy_units_kJ_g.content: Specific enthalpy change (kJ g‚Åª¬π) is the energy released or absorbed per gram of substance. This is especially useful for mixtures like petrol or coal, which don't have a single molar mass. It allows fair comparison of fuels by mass.
keyPoints: Energy per gram of substance
Essential for comparing mixtures (no single molar mass)
Also useful for mass-based comparisons of pure substances
Convert to total kJ by multiplying by mass in grams

energy_profile_exothermic.title: Exothermic Energy Profile Diagrams
energy_profile_exothermic.content: In an exothermic energy profile, reactants start at a higher energy level than products. The curve rises to a peak (transition state), then falls below the starting level. The vertical drop from reactants to products represents ŒîH (negative). Energy is released because products are more stable.
keyPoints: Reactants higher than products
ŒîH is negative (downward arrow)
Products more stable (lower energy)
Still requires activation energy to start

energy_profile_endothermic.title: Endothermic Energy Profile Diagrams
energy_profile_endothermic.content: In an endothermic energy profile, reactants start at a lower energy level than products. The curve rises to a peak (transition state), then settles above the starting level. The vertical rise from reactants to products represents ŒîH (positive). Energy is absorbed because products are less stable.
keyPoints: Products higher than reactants
ŒîH is positive (upward arrow)
Reactants more stable (lower energy)
Ea is always greater than ŒîH in endothermic reactions

stability_energy_relationship.title: Stability and Energy
stability_energy_relationship.content: There is an inverse relationship between energy and stability: lower energy means greater stability. Systems naturally tend toward lower energy states. In exothermic reactions, products are more stable (lower energy). In endothermic reactions, reactants are more stable.
keyPoints: Lower energy = more stable
Exothermic: products more stable than reactants
Endothermic: reactants more stable than products
Systems naturally move toward lower energy (stability)
